feed.title: Category: picks | User group for Viennese rubyists

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
7/8 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we'll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies... you're in for an eclectic mix! So, here's for the sixteenth edition:

Andy:
  • We still don’t really know how bicycles work - Forget mysterious dark matter and the inexplicable accelerating expansion of the universe; the bicycle represents a far more embarrassing hole in the accomplishments of physics
  • docker.io - Docker is an open-source engine which automates the deployment of applications as highly portable, self-sufficient containers.
  • Mailpile - Mailpile is a free-as-in-freedom personal e-mail searching and indexing tool, largely inspired by Google's popular proprietary-but-gratis e-mail service. Check out their fundraiser http://igg.me/at/mailpile
Floor:
  • Animated Opacity for Hangout Overlays - The Hangouts API team recently released a new feature in the Dev Channel of the Hangouts API, that allows controlling the opacity of overlays. Check out how Gerwin Sturm's has been playing around with the code to create some awesome effects.
  • Never leave the terminal - Konstantin Haase shared this great resource. Go watch it!
  • #pairwithme - We'd love to experiment a little with pair programming sessions! For the next meetup we reserve 18:00 - 19:00 for pairing, with the talks starting at 19:15. Drop by at 6pm and we'll hook you up with a partner!

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
31/7 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we'll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies... you're in for an eclectic mix! So, here's for the fifteenth edition:

Andy:
  • HTTP v2.0 draft - The first release of the Hypertext Transfer Protocol version 2.0.
  • Simple API with Nginx and PostgreSQL - How to build a simple REST API using only Nginx and PostgreSQL.
  • Regex Cross­word -Bored by regular crossword puzzles? Then level up!
Floor:
  • warrior.attack! - Code Ruby to get further in this cute game!
  • Kindergarten coders - 4-year-olds are learning to program thanks to a new graphics-based coding language
  • Deconstructing MySpace - I like onextrapixel's approach to destructing non-traditional layout

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
26/7 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we'll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies... you're in for an eclectic mix! So, here's for the fourteenth edition:

Andy:
  • Top 10 Proactive Web Application Security Measures - Security should concern everyone, from the developer to the CEO
  • pkgr - Package your Rails app into deb or rpm packages
  • fpm - Effing package managers! Build packages for multiple platforms (deb, rpm, etc) with great ease and sanity.
Floor:
  • gem install exercism - Exercism - a Katrina Owen production - is all about giving and receiving feedback. And code reviews.
  • Laber's lab - to all the makers out there, check out the dates for the Arduino lab's!
  • Sektor5 - neat post (with dito pictures) about the co-working space that hosts our monthly meetups

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
17/7 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we'll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies... you're in for an eclectic mix! So, here's for the thirteenth edition:

Andy:
  • A Hacker's Replacement for GMail - If you are willing to operate your own mailserver this is a good starting point.
  • The case against using RubyGems.org in production - A screed + a screencast showing you how to host your own gems.
  • Stickler - Stickler is a tool to organize and maintain your own gem repository.
Tony:
  • Demeter: It's not just a good idea. It's the law. - A very interesting demonstration and solutions by Avdi Grimm.
  • Swapping Rails Stack Traces for a REPL - You do like pry? Better Errors? THIS is the thing for you!
  • Adapter Registry - Store your decorators in a in-memory registry, and retrieve them in the correct context! (Shameless plug)
Floor:
  • Web Development Teaching Materials - A variety of CC-licensed web development curriculum which was developed for GirlDevelopIt SF. Useful to students as well. via @bastilian
  • The Open Source Report Card - Enter a GitHub username to see a dynamically generated progress report for their open source contributions. With graphs and charts and EVERYTHING!
  • CSS Minion - How cool is this: Minion drawn entirely using only HTML&CSS.

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
9/7 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we'll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies... you're in for an eclectic mix! So, here's for the twelfth edition:

Andy:
  • Foundations of Computer Science - Although the book has been taken out of print by W. H. Freeman, you are welcome to read it online. And I suggest you do.
  • The Elements of Style in Ruby #2 - Second in its series, topic being the following rule from the Ruby Style Guide: Favor the use of sprintf and its alias format over the fairly cryptic String#% method.
  • ALL teh bots - Do you know how to create a bot in Ruby? Now you do!
Tony:
  • Gems that need help with Rails 4 - A Gist started by Steve Klabnik
  • Bogus - a library that aims to reduce the risks associated with isolated unit testing.
  • Drain the oceans! - ... and let the Netherlands rule?
Floor:
  • console.image - The one thing Chrome Dev Tools didn't need. The day has come when you have the ability to put images in the console.
  • Programming Trends - Programming trends on StackOverflow.
  • Interview with Matz - The future of computing, the future of computer programmers - an interview with Yukihiro Matsumoto.
